awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Accelerated Detection of Successful Crop Production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is the acceleration of modern crop production by removing a key roadblock. Currently, the time and monetary investment required to generate a new crop line produces accessibility inequities to the latest improved strains. Through this project, a technology will be developed to reduce the time and cost to the commercial production pipeline. This technology will help understand the earliest steps of the crop production pipeline on the molecular level, so that projects and lines that are destined to fail can be quickly identified and removed from the production line. This early quality control will reduce the time and investment associated with the crop production pipeline, reducing the commercial investment in the process and improving accessibility to potential new crops.  
 
The proposed project  aims to detect off-type or “aberrant” RNAs in new crop lines in the early event sorting phase, after the process of transgenesis. These aberrant RNAs are unwanted, as they fail the cell’s RNA quality control mechanism and inhibit future transcription from these regions. The overall scientific goals of this project are to develop a technology that detects all the RNA generated by a plant transgene or any locus of interest, and then use this predictive information to inform breeders which lines should progress in the crop production pipeline. The research objectives are to refine the technology to identify all species of RNA generated by a transgene, and then test this predive potential on real-world crop lines provided by an industry partner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The analysis of RNA is typically either highly quantitative OR highly qualitative, with the experimenter having to choose which analysis to perform. Through this project we have established a new RNA-sequencing approach called “All-In-One RNA Sequencing'' that combines the best aspects of high-depth quantitative RNA-sequencing with the best aspects of long-read qualitative sequencing. All-In-One RNA Sequencing analyzes all of the RNAs generated by a few loci in high depth and detail. This application is ideal for the highest resolution RNA analysis of a single region of the genome or up to 50 genomic regions. In addition to the sequencing, we have developed a data analysis pipeline to visualize and quantitate the results of All-In-One RNA sequencing, which includes Machine Learning approaches to extract the key features that differentiate samples. 

 

We used All-In-One RNA Sequencing to dissect the process of transgene silencing in plants. Transgenes provide the ability to customize plant genomes to improve their traits such as disease resistance and stress tolerance. We partnered with industry to analyze soybean and corn products in the commercialization pipeline, academics that generate crop strains to provide to breeders, and we generated our own transgene silencing lines. All three of these systems were deeply analyzed by All-In-One RNA Sequencing. By comparing transgenes to consistently and robustly expressed native genes, we identified key hallmarks of the initiation of transgene silencing at two distinct timepoints. First, at the moment of silencing we see the hallmarks of RNA degradation by molecules called small interfering RNAs that act to degrade the transgene’s RNAs. Second, even before silencing is evident, we see molecular signatures that enable us to predict that a transgene will become silenced. 

 

The broader impacts of this work include a new molecular tool for researchers to dissect the RNA-level regulation of single genes at extreme depth. This project accelerated the development of a technology that itself will be used as a tool to make key discoveries across the fields of RNA biology. All-In-One RNA Sequencing can be used in any application of RNA biology, including in industry, diagnostic and therapeutic applications. Our use-case of plant transgene silencing will enable the early detection of failed product development, rather than costly late-stage failure. The data generated under this project will potentially influence the future design and engineering of crop improvement traits. This project built bridges between the academic and industry partners, and also provided a deep training experience to a postdoc through research and an industry internship.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2023
Modified by: R Keith Slotkin
